origin: “How dare they refuse to say their name in a wrong accent & not mangle their own family name so that I can feel more comfortable instead of look inside myself & examine why something as small as *a person’s name* makes me uncomfortable in the first place?? This is an outrage!” https://twitter.com/IssamAhmed/status/1108524383491055616 …
Some pundits dislike it when people of color pronounce their own names correctly  https://twitter.com/AOC/status/1108523500279599106 …
replies:
By the way: Fox News likes to say my name (incorrectly) as “Cortez,” which I can only imagine is bc that sounds more ‘stereotypically’ Hispanic + probably incites more ‘anxiety’ for them.

Pro Tip:
My last name is not “Cortez,” just as theirs isn’t “Ingra” or “Carl” or “Hann.”

My last name is Ocasio-Cortez. Full stop. That’s my name.

No, you can’t say “Cortez.” I’ve never used that in my life. “Cortez” is referring to someone else.

Even if they‘re trying to be rude + wrong, my dad’s last name was Ocasio anyway.

(His name was hyphenated too, though.)

For the curious, in Latinx culture children take *both* their parents‘ names.

It’s not a “progressive, new thing.” It’s just how some names work. PR hyphenates, others mark differently. Your last name = the families that came together to make you.

AOC is also fine though :)

Didn’t know that. 

So how does it work when both parents’ names are already hyphenated?

Also, big fan of your work!!!  Keep crushing it.

Everyone’s last names are hyphenated - so you children take the first names of each of their parents.

ex: my dad was Ocasio-ABC, my mom’s was Cortez-XYZ

So I am Ocasio-Cortez

(When they married, my mom became Ocasio-Cortez too - wives keep father’s name + take husband’s too)
Do you have a middle name or is that not done? I'm learning (thank you btw!) so this is interesting to me. Keep up the good work.

I'm obviously not AOC, but I am Puerto Rican.  Some parents give their children middle names, but not everyone has one.

For example, I have one, so I have four names: given name, middle name, father's name, and mother's name.
I’m half PR, and given this tradition, when my ma is jokingly pissed at me, she calls me by about 18 different hyphenated last names
My name is not Hyphenated  and I have both my moms and dads last names. All of our family is this way. So it really depends on your family, it's not a universal rule.   I was born in PR btw.

It's the way it's done in Spain for ages as well. So it's the Spanish influence on that Latino name culture, I guess.
Stanford even takes the effort to explain it.
 http://yuba.stanford.edu/~molinero/html/surname.html …

Technically, it's not one hyphenated last name. It's two last names. Your father's paternal last name, followed by your mother's paternal last name. In Latin America (including PR), people commonly identify themselves by their paternal last name, but we legally have 2 last names.

In Spain:

- Nobody changes their surnames when marrying
- The first surname is the father's first surname, and it's the most important one
- The second surname is the mother's first surname and it's used in forms and the like, but it's not common in daily speech

I think it's the same throughout Hispanic America. Thing is, USA documents don't allow two different spots for surnames and I guess many Hispanics choose to hyphenate them. Didn't know though they didn't like being called by only one of them.
FYI, we don't do that in America. I know quite a few people named Cortez and they only have one last name.
